Introduction

CMLIB has a complete error tracking and reporting system that can be extended into your own scripts seamlessly.

How Does It Work?

CMError is broken down in two major concepts:

  • Errors are thrown from somewhere and each error carries a level (how serious the error is), a message string (reporting what actually happened) and any number of associative objects attached via name (called attributes).
  • Errors are thrown from somewhere to a stack. By default each instance of each class that inherits the CMError class has its own error stack, but you are free to create your own stacks and divert existing class instances to a central stack. An example of this would be if you had multiple database connections. By creating your own separate stack then connecting all the database classes to your stack you would be able to handle all the database errors in one central place.

Types of Errors

Here is a generalised description of the different levels of errors that can be thrown:

Name Description
Debug These messages are for printing out very finite details about an action that may not of even needed to report an error but the messages are relevant to the debugging developer.
Notice General information about something that has occured (success or failure) that doesn't cause any problems but a tip or message for the developer.
Unavailable Are thrown when a function that may conform to an interface but does not do anything. Such as a database method that is not available with the driver you are using.
Warning A non-fatal action has occured, either the class ignored it, did it a different way or canceled the action. These messages should be noted and fixed where possible.
Deprecated You should not be using this method or function as it may be removed, renamed or redundant in a future release.
Error A non-fatal action has occured that must be attended to. Such as dividing by zero.
Exception A non-fatal action has occured and thrown an exception with an explanation. If there is no try/catch block in place the script with exit.
Fatal The script is not recoverable or being used in a way that is impossible. The script will print an error message and force exit.
